Kuwait's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Sheikh Mohammad Sabah Al- Salem Al-Sabah said oil-rich Kuwait decided to donate 500 million U.S. dollars in aid to east Sudan, the first batch of donations at the two-day event.
He said 450 million dollars will be used for the development of infrastructure and the rest will be grants for social ventures.

Mousa Mohammad Ahmad, assistant to the Sudanese President, said east Sudan sits on a strategic location and has substantial natural resources, but the region suffers from economic weakness, drought, desertification, diseases, and shortage of services including education and health services and water.
He said the Sudanese government pledged 1.572 billion dollars for education, health, water, electricity, transportation, agriculture, and irrigation projects in east Sudan.
Representatives from 39 countries, 28 institutions, as well as 73 nongovernment organizations were present at the two-day event to back up the development of east Sudan.
More pledges of aid are expected at the conference.
East Sudan that groups three states namely Kassala, Al-Gadarif and Red Sea is believed to be rich in agricultural and mining resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Iran hangs "temporary" wife of former football star for murder

TEXT.P: Iran hanged the temporary wife of a former football star on Wednesday for committing murder after she spent more than eight years in prison, the local satellite Press TV reported.
Khadijeh Shahla Jahed was found guilty in 2002 of stabbing Laleh Saharkhizan, the wife of former Iranian football star Nasser Mohammadkhani, said the report.
Jahed had been living with the football player in the 1980s in the Iranian capital of Tehran under a contract of temporary marriage arrangement, according to the report.
Temporary marriage in Iran is a legal way of outside marriage for men.

Jahed was hanged at Evin prison at local time 5:00 a.m. (0130 GMT) on Wednesday after the verdict was confirmed by Iran's Supreme Court and Judiciary Chief Ayatollah Sadeq Amoli Larijani, her lawyer Abdolsamad Khoramshahi was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Roundup: Haneya says to respect any outcome of Palestinian referendum on peace

TEXT.P: by Fares Akram

GAZA, Dec. 1 (Xinhua) -- Hamas will respect any Palestinian referendum on a peaceful settlement with Israel even if the agreement was against its agenda, deposed Prime Minister of the Hamas government Ismail Haneya said Wednesday.

"The (Hamas) government's program includes the creation of a Palestinian statehood within the borders of lands that Israel occupied in 1967," Haneya said at a press conference held at his office in Gaza city.

However, if another solution was reached through peace talks between Israel and the Palestinian National Authority (PNA), whose chances of success was questioned by Haneya, "there would be a referendum and Hamas will respect its results, even if it contradicts its policies," Haneya said.

Meanwhile, Haneya said his government will maintain an undeclared ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinian factions in the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip through 2011, which, he noted was one of his government's "priorities in the coming year."
However, he said if Israel attacks Gaza, Hamas "will resist and will not surrender."

Haneya noted that Israel "asked its allies in Europe" to launch a campaign to show Gaza as the source of threat to the Jewish state. He said the campaign was based on allegations that militants from Gaza had fired rockets laden with white phosphorus warheads into Israel, and that al-Qaida has managed to have cells in the Israeli-besieged coastal enclave.
"There is no al-Qaida in Gaza," Haneya said, adding that the killing of three militants, members of an al-Qaida inspired group, by Israel last month, was "a dangerous assassinations."

The Hamas government "has made sure that there are only Palestinian resistance factions working only inside Palestine," Haneya said, adding Israeli reports that activists of the Army of Islam had planned to kidnap Israelis in the nearby Sinai Peninsula were false.
Besides, Haneya underlined the effects of an international isolation on his administration which refuses to recognize Israel or renounce violence.
"There is a problem in the visits of European delegations to Gaza," and that official delegations, which mostly involve foreign ministers, don't coordinate their visits with his government, he said.

"We don't understand why they don't meet the elected government. " As a result, the Hamas government started contacting the UN Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), which arranges Gaza tours for Western diplomats, to resolve the problem. "The visitors must knock the door before they enter."
He also called Europe to reconsider its position that bans official talks with Hamas. The United States led the international campaign to boycott Hamas when it won parliamentary elections in 2006.
Talking about the Israeli blockade on the Gaza Strip, Haneya said the relaxation the blockade that the Western diplomats come to inspect is not exist.
"Israel is lying in its claims that it has eased the blockade," he said, noting "there is a political, social economical siege and Israel has only done marginal changes."

Israel imposed the blockade when Hamas captured an Israeli soldier from his base near Gaza in June 2006, but tightened it a year later when Hamas routed Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas's forces and took over Gaza.

Haneya called on Germany, which mediates between Hamas and Israel, to fasten the discussions to exchange Gilad Shalit, the captive soldier, for Arab and Palestinian prisoners, saying "we need an honorable swap."
Meanwhile, Haneya said Hamas "is ready to make the needed concessions" to reconcile with Abbas's Fatah party, which is now holding sway in the West Bank.

But he said the reconciliation should not include "a political price at the expense of the Palestinians" and it must secure political partnership between Hamas and Fatah, and the rest of the factions in the political life.
Asked if he talks to Abbas, Haneya said he tried to contact Abbas over the phone on several occasions, but Abbas rejected the calls.

Abbas fired a Hamas-led government when the Islamic movement seized Gaza in 2007, but Hamas continued ruling Gaza. Recently, Abbas said that the PNA's security services should remain outside the frame of any future deal with Hamas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jordan's stock market index closes lower

TEXT.P: AMMAN, Dec. 1 (Xinhua) - The shares price index of Jordan's Amman stock market closed at 2,345 points on Wednesday, 9 points lower from Tuesday's finish.
A total of 17 million shares were traded through 6,342 transactions. The turnover was 11.2 million Jordanian dinars (about 16 million U.S. dollars).

DOC.HEADLINE: Iran says foreign investment up 95 pct: minister

TEXT.P: Iranian Economy Minister Shamseddin Hosseini said that there has been a 95-percent leap in foreign investments in Iran from last year, local satellite Press TV reported on Wednesday.

Foreign investment in the Islamic Republic topped three billion U.S. dollars currently and is expected to grow, the minister said on Tuesday, attributing the rise to the overall security and abundant investment opportunities in Iran, according to the report.
"Iran's economic appeal and its overall security is suitable for investment," he was quoted as saying.

The minister's remarks came amid successive sanctions of the UN Security Council, the United States and its Western allies against Iran in the past years over the country's refusal to halt its sensitive nuclear program.

The United States, European Union and some other western allies believe Iran's nuclear program is moving to the atomic weaponry developments. However, Tehran denied the allegations, claiming that its nuclear program is aimed at civilian and peaceful purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sudanese gov't vows to protect oil field workers regardless of referendum result

TEXT.P: The Sudanese government on Wednesday vowed to ensure security and safety of all the workers in the country's oil fields whatever the result of south Sudan referendum is.

"The Sudanese government reiterates its commitment to provide security, safety and suitable work environment for all the workers at the different oil fields in the country," said Sudanese Vice- President Ali Osman Mohamed Taha on a celebration of increasing Al- Fula oil field production in Kordofan State Wednesday.
He added that a package of security arrangements to sustain security at the oil areas will be adopted regardless of the referendum results.

Meanwhile, Taha hailed that the productivity increase of Al- Fula oil field for extra 30,000 barrels a day was a real addition to the country's financial resources, saying "this is an accomplishment with which Sudan responses to those who question the promising future of the country in both cases of unity or separation. The Sudanese people are determined to abort all conspiracies of the enemies."
Besides, Taha said his country appreciates the partners from friendly countries to invest in agriculture, livestock raising, and infrastructure construction.
Oil income consists 90 percent of Sudan's foreign revenues and 45 percent of its general budget, and it tends to further increase its oil productivity in the coming years.

A referendum on self-determination for southern Sudan is scheduled to be conducted on Jan. 9, 2011 as it was stipulated by the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) inked between north and south Sudan in 2005, which ended a two- decade civil war between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Turkish deputy PM calls for international cooperation against corruption

TEXT.P: Turkish Deputy Prime Minister Cemil Cicek on Wednesday called for international cooperation to fight corruption.

"Corruption is a cross-border crime today," Cicek told the International Conference on Anti-corruption Measures in Turkey and Around the Globe jointly organized by the government and the UN Development Program (UNDP) here.
There was a noticeable connection between terrorism and corruption, as terrorist organizations earned a significant part of their money from corruption crimes, he said.
The anti-corruption conference, to last till Thursday, aims to share anti- corruption knowledge and experience and help Turkey intensify efforts to fight corruption.

The conference marked the beginning of a project launched by the UNDP Turkey and the Turkish government to lay the ground for a long-term partnership in the design and implementation of effective anti-corruption activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli FM acts to prevent airport security humiliation of VIPs

TEXT.P: Concerned by recent incidents in which VIPs visiting Israel were harassed, at times humiliated, by airport security checks, Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman Tuesday directed his ministry to draw a plan meant to assist innocent tourists or senior officials in case of need.

The plan calls for the establishment of a permanent situation room at the Ben- Gurion International Airport that would be staffed by officials from several government ministries, local daily Ha' aretz reported on Wednesday.

In cases in which a foreign tourist or official would be delayed for particularly lengthy questioning by airport security personnel, or when harsher security measures, including deportation, are considered, the situation room would intervene and possibly prevent faulty judgment.
Incidents of this kind "cause serious diplomatic and image damage to Israel," a Foreign Ministry official, who spoke with Ha 'aretz, quoted Lieberman as saying at Tuesday's meeting.
Security measures at Ben-Gurion, Israel's national gateway, are considered to be among the most stringent in the world, and are determined and supervised by the Shin Bet security agency.

But good intentions at times result in innocent travelers mistakenly marked as posing risk. Several high-profile incidents in which prominent visitors were wrongfully humiliated, occurred over the past year.

In May, Ivan Prado, a professional clown hailing from Spain, who had planned to participate in a festival in Ramallah, was denied entry to Israel after being wrongfully accused by Shin Bet of having ties to terrorist elements. Two months later, University of Miami President Donna Shalala went through a degrading security check prior to her return flight, solely because of her Lebanese origin.
According to official data published recently by the Tourism Ministry, a record number of tourists arrived in Israel during 2010, exactly three million by mid- November.

Lieberman reportedly told participants at the meeting that in order to maintain the flow of tourists, Israel has to ensure that they don't leave back home with "a bad taste in their mouths," the Foreign Ministry official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two policemen killed in bomb attack in western Iraq

TEXT.P: Two policemen were killed and two others wounded in a roadside bomb explosion targeted a police convoy in Iraq's Anbar province on Wednesday, a provincial police source said.

The attack took place in the afternoon near the al-Qaim city to the Iraqi-Syrian border when a roadside bomb struck the convoy of Mohammed Abdul-Majeed, the police chief of the city, the source told Xinhua on condition of anonymity.
Two of Majeed's guards were killed and two others wounded by the powerful blast which destroyed two of the convoy's vehicles, the source said.
However, Majeed himself survived the attack without injury, the source added.

Insurgent attacks continue in the once volatile Sunni Arab area in west of Baghdad that stretches through Anbar province to Iraq's western borders with Syria, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. The vast desert area has been relatively calm for more than three years after Sunni tribes and anti-U.S. insurgent groups turned to cooperate with the U.S. troops and Iraqi security forces against al- Qaida network in Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: Urgent: Egypt's Wafd party withdraws from election

TEXT.P: The liberal Wafd opposition party announced on Wednesday its withdrawal from Egypt's parliamentary election amid accusations that the vote was rigged, according its official website.

DOC.HEADLINE: Iran says "basic questions" should be addressed in talks with G5+1

TEXT.P: Iran's chief nuclear negotiator Saeed Jalili said Wednesday Iran's essential questions should be answered in the upcoming talks with the five UN Security Council permanent members and Germany (G5+1), the official IRNA news agency reported.
Speaking to reporters on the sidelines of the funeral procession for an assassinated academic, Jalili said the West should respond to Tehran's basic questions in the talks.

He was quoted as saying that "they (Westerners) used all possible ploys, including resolution, sanctions and political pressures, against us, and getting assured of their futility, have now resorted to assassination. This is sign of their desperation and failure."
These are Iran's questions and "we look forward to hearing responses to such questions in the talks," said Jalili according to IRNA.

Iranian officials have accused the West and Israel for assassination attempts on two Iranian nuclear scientists. In two separate terrorist acts in northern Tehran early Monday, Iranian nuclear scientist Majid Shahriari was killed and Fereidoon Abbasi was wounded when they were driving to work.
The European Union (EU) and Iran are expected to hold talks on Dec. 6 and 7 in Geneva, Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hamas court sentences policeman to death

TEXT.P: A Hamas military court on Wednesday sentenced a Hamas policeman to death for killing a Palestinian man in a Gaza City market last month.
The verdict, which would be carried out by a firing squad, can be appealed to the higher court, a statement by the Hamas interior ministry said.
The murderer was not in his official duty when he shot dead a person and wounded the second in the market, the statement said.
Over the past months, Hamas has carried out the execution of three people convicted of murder crimes and two accused of collaborating with Israel.

By carrying out the executions, Hamas bypass a key article in the Palestinian law that the president of the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) must ratify the death sentences. The sentences also provoked human rights groups in Gaza and officials in the PNA.
Jamil Sarhan, director of the Independent Commission for Human Rights (ICHR) in Gaza, said that the Hamas courts in Gaza "lack the standards of fair trial."
Hamas is locked in a power struggle with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, since it routed his forces and took over Gaza in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Turkish police seizes 174 kg hashish

TEXT.P: The Turkish police Wednesday seized 174 kg of hashish in four separate operations in Turkey's southeastern province of Diyarbakir, the semi-official Anatolia news agency reported.
Three people, who had been detained in the operations, were later arrested, according to the report.

On Tuesday, Turkish police stopped a car on Tarsus-Gaziantep highway in southeastern Gaziantep province and searched out 61.4 kg of heroin stashed in the vehicle, said the report, adding five suspects were detained in the operation.
Turkey is a key transit route for smuggling drugs from Asia and the Middle East to markets in western Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Feature: Olive: Syria's ancient green old

TEXT.P: Legend claims that olive trees appeared first in ancient Syria, nearly 6,000 years ago, before expanding to the rest of the Mediterranean basin.

Nowadays, 6,000 years after the spread of olive cultivation from Syria to the Mediterranean region, Syria is still among the leading producers of olive oil around the world with over 640,000 hectares of olive orchards and some 100 million olive trees.

Do you know that the normal life span of olive tree is 500 to 900 years? There are even trees alive in the Mediterranean basin that are over 1,000 years, said Mohamad al-Ahmad, 47 years old, an olive farm owner In Idlib, 350 km north to Syria's capital of Damascus.

"I have this olive farm estimated at 27 acres, planted with olive trees since 1996. Each tree produces 20 kg to 30 kg of olive annually, and every 5 kg of olive extracts 1 kg of oil," al- Ahamad said, "This olive farm provides me some 4,000 U.S. dollars a year, " he added.

"Thousands of Syrian families depend on olive fruits and olive oil products to live, olive trees are considered as treasure as many of Syrian families grew, educated and covered their costs through olives and olive oil industry," Firas Sweid, the Syrian chairman of olive chamber, told Xinhua.

Olive oil has many valuable uses beyond cooking, from personal care to home improvement and natural remedies, but olive oil often goes bad under the best storage conditions in a few years. Light and heat are its enemies. Storage in a dark cool cupboard or in dark glass or tin is preferable.

Storage in a refrigerator is fine but the oil will turn almost solid so you must warm it before using. Keep only a small amount next to the range where you need it for cooking as the heat from cooking degrades it.

Olive oil is known to be gentle on the digestive system, and even may help prevent gallstones and soothe ulcers. Good quality olive oil contains valuable vitamins and nutrients, and it is loaded with antioxidants, which many believe help protect the body from cancer.

However, Syrian farmers now worry about the future of their olive farms especially after Syrian agriculture ministry decided that allow only big companies to export olive products, as well as the severe competitions from Spain and Italy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Turkey's export growth slow to 7.3 pct in November

TEXT.P: Turkey's exports increased by 7.3 percent to 9.4 billion U.S. dollars year-on- year in November, a slower growth than last month, local media reported Wednesday.
The rate was lower than the 8.8 percent rise in exports in October, according to figures cited by the semi-official Anatolia news agency from the Turkish Exporters Assembly (TIM).
In the January to November period, exports rose 10.9 percent year-on-year to 102.1 billion dollars, the report said.
Automotive industry outpaced other sectors with an export volume of 1.3 billion dollars in November, followed by textile and chemical, it said.
Most of the exports went to Germany, followed by Britain, Iraq, Italy, France and Russia, data showed.

Turkish State Minister for Foreign Trade Zafer Caglayan said Iran, United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Syria, Israel, Germany, Russia, Iraq and China were among the countries to which Turkish exports saw a significant rise, Anatolia reported.
Turkey targets 111.7 billion dollars of exports for 2010 and 127 billion dollars for 2011, according to the report.
